byline.contributor: Yolanne Almanzar contributed reporting from Miami.

docs.lead_paragraph: Even before the recession, more than one in five Americans could not pay for basic needs without help from family, friends or outsiders, according to a survey by the Census Bureau. Fourteen percent of all Americans and 26 percent of blacks who responded to the 2005 survey reported that at sometime in the preceding year they were not able to meet essential expenses on their own, like paying bills for basic needs, avoiding foreclosure and buying sufficient food.

headline.main: In Survey, Hard Times Before Slump

docs.snippet: One in five Americans needed help paying for basic needs, according to a 2005 census survey.

docs.lead_paragraph: On the eve of a crucial Senate vote on health care legislation, the Obama administration on Friday distributed a bipartisan message of support from Tommy G. Thompson, a Republican who served as health secretary to President George W. Bush, and Richard A. Gephardt, a former Democratic leader of the House. Mr. Thompson, right, and Mr. Gephardt said that while they had ''specific concerns with the bill in its current form,'' they believed that it represented ''another milestone in achieving meaningful health care reform for millions of Americans.''
docs.abstract: Obama administration, on eve of crucial Senate vote on health care legislation, distributes bipartisan message of support from Tommy G Thompson, Republican who served as health secretary to Pres George W Bush, and Richard A Gephardt, former Democratic leader of House; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Why are health insurance premiums increasing so fast for so many small employers? Some Democratic members of Congress want to know. In a strongly worded letter to the trade association representing the nation's health insurers, 31 senators and 88 representatives wrote, ''Small businesses and hard-working Americans deserve to know why they will be subjected to such unusual and significant increases in health premiums, and we ask you to submit to Congress a detailed explanation of the planned rate hikes.''
docs.abstract: Some Democratic members of Congress, in letter to America's Health Insurance Plans, demand to know why health insurance premiums are increasing so fast for small employers; letter is signed by 31 senators and 88 representatives (S)
docs.snippet: Why are health insurance premiums increasing so fast for so many small employers? Some Democratic members of Congress want to know.     In a strongly worded letter to the trade association representing the nation's health insurers, 31 senators and 88...

docs.lead_paragraph: When former President Bill Clinton joined Senate Democrats for lunch last week to exhort them to pass sweeping health care legislation, he made a point of naming one senator whom he blamed for helping to kill Mr. Clinton's own effort to overhaul the health care system in 1994: Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who was senior senator from New York.

headline.main: N.Y. View on Health Care, 15 Years Later

docs.abstract: New York's current senior senator has a different stance on a health care overhaul than a mentor did in '94.
docs.snippet: New York's current senior senator has a different stance on a health care overhaul than a mentor did in '94.

docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Conference of Catholic Bishops, fresh off their abortion victory on health care legislation in the House, has joined the battle in the Senate and called for the same amendment that it pushed through the House.
docs.abstract: U.S. Conference of Bishops, fresh off their abortion victory on health care legislation in the House, has called for adding the same amendment to the Senate bill.
docs.snippet: U.S. Conference of Bishops, fresh off their abortion victory on health care legislation in the House, has called for adding the same amendment to the Senate bill.

docs.lead_paragraph: So exactly why are health insurance premiums increasing so fast for so many small employers? Some Democratic members of Congress want to know.

docs.lead_paragraph: In today's Patient Money column, Lesley Alderman writes about how those with minimal or no health insurance can still find ways to get the psychological help they may need.

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, and one of three members of his party who had expressed reservations about starting debate on the major health care legislation, has issued a statement saying that he will vote to bring the bill to the floor.

headline.main: Senator Nelson Will Vote to Start Health Debate

docs.abstract: Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, says he will support the motion to bring the health care legislation to the Senate floor for debate.
docs.snippet: Senator Ben Nelson, Democrat of Nebraska, says he will support the motion to bring the health care legislation to the Senate floor for debate.
